content.description: Start on the corner on the left side of the Watkin's roof. Make powerful moves trending right out from underneath the roof until you can join Watkin's Roof Left.
content.location: Watkin's Roof is one of the last large boulders you encounter at Heaven Boulders. It faces the cliffline.

content.description: Compression masterpiece located in the boonies of Arkansas. Beautiful stone and movement on this one. Must do for the area.Down the trail past Flash Mode to the first obvious big boulder with chalk on it separate from the cliff line.  The Wasp starts on the down hill side of the boulder under the overhang on obvious iron jugs.  Move up and right on more good holds until getting into the slopers, and exit left.
Harder than it looks. Finish out left and over the lip.
content.location: To the right of the wasp. Start on the same jug as the Wasp.

content.description: Sit start on a jug on the left arete. Traverse right through edges and crimps until you are able to move up to the jug ledge. Finish by standing on the ledge.
content.location: Climber’s left of Watkins Roof. This problem starts at the end of a little corridor formed by the boulders.

content.description: Start matched on the sloper rail. Move up and left using crimps to gain the finish jug at 10ft.
content.location: To the (climber's) left of Watkins Roof.

content.description: Start matched on the sloper rail. Move up using small sidepulls to reach the finish jug at 12 ft.
content.location: Climber's left of the Watkins Roof.

content.description: Please document the name and FA if you know.Starts on jugs under a small roof, with feet on a good shelf. Keep your feet low and compress your way out the roof until you gain a good left hand. Get the feet up and finish with easier 5th class climbing.
content.location: On the south side of the Wasp boulder.

content.description: Pulling the move to reach the last Jug is a bit spooky. Watch out for a chossy chicken head flake on the topout. Might break down or fall off soon.
content.protection: A couple of pads and spotters.
content.location: Start on the lowest jug in the bottom right of the mini cave. Climb up and right. Great long moves.

content.description: Awkward start low on some good crimps.  make moves into juggy, right facing vertical flake.  A couple more moves sets you up for the crux throw to a bad pinch straight up. Reset and jump for glory jugs and an easy topout.
content.protection: couple of pads.  Landing is flat, but the dyno at the end is a bit off balance.
content.location: On the same boulder as the Wasp and Flying Squirrel. When looking at flying squirel, it is about 50 left, after the boulder starts rounding uphill.  Easy to spot the prominent, right facing vertical jug rail at about hip height.  It is about three feet long and ends around chest height for me.

content.description: Shares a start and the first couple of moves with Flash Mode, then busts straight out the overhang with some very unique sequencing.  Don't blow the heartbreaker final moves!
content.location: The first problems approached, this one (along with Flash Mode) will be on your right when passing the short cliff line on the way to The Wasp boulder.  These two are the only chalked up lines on the cliff currently.

content.description: Follow the crack feature with great holds surrounding it

Really neat tension problem with some power moves mixed in.  Start with left hand on a small crimp and right hand on a crimpy undercling.  Move up somewhat slopey holds with bad feet into a tough deadpoint.  Everything is on, especially the feet out right (hint hint); as long as you use the proper start holds, I dont believe there is any way to contrive.  The problem tops out very high on easy ground.
content.location: Backside of boulder with Watkin's Roof.  If looking at Rare Breed/Distilled, turn around and walk the opposite direction, taking to the downhill side of the adjacent boulder and hugging it around.  The problem will be visible soon after (not the new problems on the adjacent boulder, but straight ahead on the house-size block). It is on the right side of the big roof that is on the downhill side.

content.description: Not quite as high quality as The Wasp, but very very good. This thing builds, starting with some easier moves on pinches that get harder and harder until ending in a compression crux and a stopper final move that sends many climbers flying.  After the crux, there is still 10 feet or so of easier climbing to a high but easy topout. Would reccomend doing the crack to the left and sussing out this topout as a warm up.
content.protection: pads. crux moves don't get very high off the ground, but top-out is a bit tall.
content.location: Down the trail past Flash Mode to the first obvious big boulder with chalk on it separate from the cliff line.  The Flying Squirrel, same as The Wasp, starts on the down hill side of the boulder under the overhang on obvious iron jugs.  If looking at the wall facing uphill, this problem will start in the bottom right and move left through down facing pinches, a tiny left hand crimp, and the fat block above.

content.description: Start low on a jug, then come out to the crimps.  Leftward traverse on small crimps leads to either a desperate sideways throw/dyno, or some gnarly crossover.  Boulder was famously put up by Nalle as a flash in the waning hours of the day.
content.protection: couple of pads and a spotter
content.location: The first problems approached, this one (along with Mujahideen) will be on your right when passing the short cliff line on the way to The Wasp boulder.  These two are the only chalked up lines on the cliff currently.

content.description: Same start holds as “Rare Breed” but traverse left along jugs to the left edge of the overhang. Round the arête and use a perfect pinch, jug and/or hand jam to continue up the left face. Top out straight up the crack system on dirty rock.
content.location: Go to the wasp and turn right.  Head straight ahead (with the wasp boulder to your right) and there will be a big boulder straight in front of you.  Keep going until you can turn left around this boulder, and you will see the obvious line of jugs splitting this face.  Start on the furthest right jug, head left and around the corner to top out.

content.description: A small collection of boulders off County rd 37. Hosts the classic compression masterpiece "The Wasp"
